TopicTitle: Will my new PC see performance gains for 1.1.x?

Articles.Content:
So today I'm finally assembling my new PC which is going to combine some old parts from my current rig with new parts I bought.  I am happy that I managed to put this thing together for less then $400 bucks.  It's not a beastly creature or anything but it was the best I could do with limited free income.

Current (Ye Olde Puter):  Dell XPS (3.0 ghz 4-core phenom, 8 gigs Fury-X ram, ancient 7200 rpm HDD, R7 260 card (2 gig))

Replacement:  Custom built (3.5 ghz (max 5.0) 8 core FX 8230, same 8 gigs Fury-X, 250 GB SSHD, same R7 card).  Also with a nice Hyper 212 Evo air cooler for light overclocking.

I'll shamefully admit KSP was one of the main drivers for the upgrade, excluding the fact that my current rig is 7 years old and difficult to further upgrade (being a Dell).  It has, however, served me well.  I've also started getting into playing with Unreal Engine and Visual Studio and hope the extra processing power will speed up rendering.

Will I notice any gains for KSP?  I figure the extra cores may allow more ships in a scene, even if it is an AMD processor.  

 

Gods this sounds bitter but:  Please don't bash on my hardware.  I don't want to debate about AMD vs. intel or any such.  I just get what I get the best deal for and what will work for me.  (I've had some bad experiences on PCPartPicker getting attacked for my choices).

Going from one AMD to another, faster, AMD CPU should have better results. The extra cores might help, but probably not by too much. The change to an SSD will make most things seem faster, but with KSP you probably won't see much difference. 

If you've already got the parts in, then the best way to tell if it makes KSP run any better is to fire up KSP and see!

 

(Also, I believe this belongs in a different subforum. Perhaps the Lounge, as it isn't directly KSP related)

Edited May 2, 2016 by magico13
Have you tried 1.1 on the old config? I have a potent PC but a large craft on 1.05 made me wanted to cut my wrists. 1.1 made that all go away.
You should not have any problems with your old machine...
You'll see, compared to 1.05, 1.1 is much more smooth and stable.

I suspect that the biggest change you will see out of your new rig is scene loading time improvements with the SSD.  Hopefully 1.1 will show a few more improvements with the new CPU.  Don't expect too much: going from single threaded to four threads will typically use up most of the improvements, going to 8 won't show nearly as many.  Also the AMD "8 core" CPUs share only 4 floating point units.  Since the new "multi-threaded code" is entirely about physics (which is typically all floating point), don't expect all 8 cores to play nicely with each other in the cases when you have 8 threads running.

Still, I've been running an AMD 8320 and found it working well on 1.0.5 and before (for not overly-large vessels) and even better for 1.1 and beyond (although I haven't made anything big yet).  I suspect that if your GPU can render it, your CPU will be able to do its side of the physics.

Put it this way: I have a AMD 8320, a nvidia 560i, and an "all in one" water cooler for the CPU (there was this sale...).  Nothing in KSP has made me want to see just how far I can overclock the CPU.

On 5/2/2016 at 1:22 PM, magico13 said:

Going from one AMD to another, faster, AMD CPU should have better results. The extra cores might help, but probably not by too much. The change to an SSD will make most things seem faster, but with KSP you probably won't see much difference. 

If you've already got the parts in, then the best way to tell if it makes KSP run any better is to fire up KSP and see!

 

(Also, I believe this belongs in a different subforum. Perhaps the Lounge, as it isn't directly KSP related)

Ooo yea I probably put this in the wrong sub-forum.  Whoops.  Any mod can move it that sees this.

I just spent an entire night fighting a corsair 16 pin.  Almost finished with it and after I get win7 loaded I think I may fire up KSP first anyways hehe.  But yea 1.1 made a huge difference even with this rig.
